awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Metal Organic Nanoparticles (MONPs) for Supramolecularly Assisted Covalent Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
A wide range of important organic compounds, including pharmaceutical agents, are prepared from simpler, commercially available materials. The synthesis of these organic compounds often takes several steps, some of which involve metal-based catalysts. Developing catalysts that give higher yields and operate in water reduces both the amount of volatile organic solvents used and the heavy metal waste, thus, making these synthetic processes more sustainable. With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Prof. Steven C. Zimmerman at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is developing nanoscale, polymer-based metal catalysts that can perform such reactions in water and, because of their low toxicity, even in human cells. Thus, a broader impact of the work is the creation of a nanoscale robot, a "nanobot" that selectively enter certain types of cells and prepare bioactive agents from smaller, cell-permeable, but inactive small molecules. Another broader impact is the training of a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students.

The research team at the University of Illinois is developing new polymeric catalysts, prepared by ring-opening metathesis polymerization, that expand the types of reactions performed. Optimized metal-organic polymeric nanoparticles (MONPs) are designed to catalyze the copper-assisted "click" reaction, the palladium-catalyzed Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reaction, and the ruthenium-mediated ring-closing metathesis reaction. The hydrophobic interior of these MONPs is designed to allow the reactions to proceed in water at low concentrations of catalyst by taking advantage of the hydrophobic interior of the nanoparticles. Efforts are directed toward the preparation of MONPs that contain two different catalytic centers to allow sequential, orthogonal processes to occur, increasing the complexity and power of the MONP approach. Finally, an ONP that modularly binds metal catalysts using hydrophobic binding is being pursued as a more universal, plug-and-play strategy.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Proteins are biomolecules that perform a wide array of essential functions for life, including DNA replication, nutrient transport, metabolism, and signaling. One of the most important functions is their ability to catalyze a wide range of chemical reactions in the complex environment of a living organism. Proteins are capable of performing these tasks in part because they fold into well-defined three-dimensional structures that are programmed (determined) by their constituent amino acid sequence. Thus, the sequence of the 22 naturally occurring amino acids determines the shape (structure) and function of a protein. 

One of the goals of this project was to determine whether synthetic polymers might be able to fold in a manner that is analogous to proteins and, whether like enzymes they might bind substrates and catalyze reactions. Synthetic polymers are not limited to the 22 natural amino acids, thus offering the potential to greatly expand the types of chemical reactions that can be catalyzed. 

We focused on metal containing polymers that perform chemical reactions at very low concentrations and reactions that have no counterpart in nature. Why low concentrations? Because we wanted our artificial metalloenzymes to potentially synthesize drug molecules for therapeutic purposes. The therapeutic concentration of drugs is very low meaning our artificial enzymes could provide a means to bring substrates and the active metal center together whereas without the polymeric artificial enzyme the chance encounter of the substrates and metal catalyst would unlikely happen. Furthermore the polymer can protect the metal ion from the competitive environment found within cells and the organism.

We developed two artificial metalloenzymes. The first contained copper ions and catalyzed a very important chemical reaction called the “click” reaction. This reaction has found broad utility in numerous areas, including in drug discovery, chemical biological studies, and in the preparation of useful materials. The polymeric copper catalyst we developed performs the click reaction between the two molecular substrates (called azide and alkyne) at very low concentrations and faster than any known catalyst. The artificial copper-containing enzyme, which we call a “clickase,” was able to enter bacterial cells and perform a click reaction to make an antibiotic agent, which killed the bacteria. This was the first demonstration of a designed artificial enzyme of this type synthesizing a bioactive agent, a drug, in a living organism.

The second artificial metalloenzyme contained a ruthenium complex that upon activation with light performed a chemical reaction wherein a group called an azide is reduced to a group called an amine. We found that the artificial enzyme entered living cells and performed the reduction reaction quite efficiently. Remarkably, we further showed that the artificial enzyme could bind to a naturally occurring enzyme called beta-galactosidase and help carry this enzyme into the cell. We showed that the natural and artificial enzymes could simultaneously catalyze reactions within a living mammalian cell. One application we demonstrated was the ability of this pair to unmask two separate anti-cancer agents. This exciting result suggests a new way to increase the selectivity and efficacy of a combination therapy. Thus, the anti-cancer drugs are only unmasked and activated when the artificial and natural enzymes and light are all present at the same time and in the same place.

Finally, using support from the Special Creativity Extension, we have succeeded in developing a new monomer that can be used to make a range of polymeric materials that undergo rapid breakdown under very specific conditions. This effort is directed toward increasing the sustainability of plastics and other polymeric materials. With our new CATCH cleavage monomer, we were able to prepare a new type of polyurethane that performs identical to commercial polyurethanes, but is able to be broken down rapidly and under very mild conditions after the useful life of the polyurethane material. Importantly, the products of the breakdown can be used to create new materials, such as coatings and strong adhesives, giving the original polymers a second life. What is a significant advance in this type of upcycling is ability to degrade the original polymer at room temperature in a matter of minutes with a very specific set of chemical reagents. Most processes that degrade polymers require high temperatures and lengthy times making them energy intensive.

To date, this project has produced 16 papers published in refereed journals with additional papers yet to come. Additionally, one patent was filed on technology produced by the project. A diverse group of students were trained under this project, including nine graduate and five undergraduate students. Multiple students have entered the workforce and several have continued productive academic careers.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: Steven C Zimmerman

Image
  • Schematic drawing of an artificial metalloenzyme, represented by the round CAT residing in a cell and catalyzing the chemical linking of two small molecules, making a large coupled, bioactive molecule that might not have easily entered the cell.
    Yugang Bai
    Copyrighted
    Steven C Zimmerman
    Cartoon of human cell with artificial enzyme catalyzing coupling reaction inside
